item.title: The more Marine Le Pen’s nationalist-populist manifesto has come under scrutiny, the wider Emmanuel Macron’s lead has become. This was particularly evident during their head-to-head debate https://t.co/21CXns688d
This week America, Britain and Canada said they would provide Ukraine with heavy artillery—it's a step in the right direction https://t.co/pDl6B05L4O
Crying over spilt milk? The fate of a valuable dairy company illustrates the flaws of the Egyptian economy https://t.co/or3xhJgkxE
European sanctions have all but ignored Russian oil and gas. The continent has paid nearly €40bn for Russian energy since the war in Ukraine started eight weeks ago https://t.co/rOHuco7TFr
The Moskva was nearly the length of two football pitches and protected by three layers of air defence. How could an underdog have inflicted such a significant naval loss? https://t.co/KYnPPnJTry

This weekend French voters return to the polls to pick their next president. The Economist’s forecasting model says Emmanuel Macron has a very high chance of winning the presidency.
Explore the model here👇
Elon Musk says he has received funding to finance a takeover of Twitter, and that he is exploring whether to launch a tender offer to all Twitter shareholders https://t.co/xrgfGvZZeA

Poland has “warned for more than a decade” against appeasing Vladimir Putin, writes the country’s prime minister in a guest essay. “But we have been met with suspicion and even contempt” https://t.co/WNt7imORne
The jazz bassist’s entire works are now in the Library of Congress, the first time a jazz composer had received that accolade https://t.co/0dD7yKNcVv

Rwanda has one of Africa’s scariest, most repressive governments. Britain has accurately criticised its human-rights violations in the past, although it may refrain from now on https://t.co/zN1pkdYXs2

The UN has named Sir David Attenborough a Champion of the Earth.
This #EarthDay, listen to the naturalist speak about the human impact on the environment, on an episode of “The Economist Asks” from our archive https://t.co/exVuHm3ZA3 https://t.co/J9D9MpPHBs
Ukraine’s display of prowess may encourage allies to provide more of the anti-ship missiles that they have promised, a colonel in Kyiv told us https://t.co/mtBVpeceLc
Europe has more options to substitute Russian oil than Russia has options to replace European customers. This should incentivise the EU to impose tariffs https://t.co/wgRShlb4Fo
What Elon Musk builds is the work of genius. But when it comes to Twitter, he is often childish https://t.co/dzZWjR1K78

The death toll in Mariupol, Ukraine’s most-bombarded city, is unknown. But satellite imagery paints a grim picture of the destruction.
Read more about how satellite imagery provides clues to what is happening in the city

Why did Vladimir Putin, knowing the enormous costs, decide to invade Ukraine? The author of “Why We Fight” provides five rationales for war https://t.co/r9DPPxpw53
“Russia has committed atrocities and, unless it is stopped, images such as those seen in Bucha, Irpin and Mariupol will appear more often,” warns @MorawieckiM in a guest essay https://t.co/EWE511UfP4
European sanctions have all but ignored Russian oil and gas. The continent has paid nearly €40bn for Russian energy since the war in Ukraine started eight weeks ago https://t.co/FC0VJEmi5F
America’s central bank had the tools to stop inflation and failed to use them in time. The result is the worst overheating in a big and rich economy in 30 years https://t.co/Rly1d6U2QX
For Ukraine to hold the Russians back, let alone force them to retreat from the territory seized since the war began, will take heavier weapons https://t.co/RGRUipOO3d

If you can't embargo Russian oil and gas, you should tax it.
Imposing tariffs on imports of Russian energy is a good way to hobble Putin. It's easier to do than sanctions. Something for the EU to consider.
My Charlemagne this week: https://t.co/jSvehJWZHd https://t.co/J6i4Gn8JpC
The world’s richest man is playing with the rules of the game—and taking the world of business in a reckless new direction https://t.co/VeTIrlX9bg

If China were to invade, Taiwan’s priority should be to hold out. Look at Ukraine: the longer it has fought, the more help it has received from others
https://t.co/MsZsIPxRtn
Ukraine needs more help https://t.co/6hn5y22OPd
Some economists reckon tariffs on Russian hydrocarbons would even help the EU turn a profit at Russia’s expense https://t.co/UTLlf4YwNx

“The demons of history have returned. We are witnessing genocide again,” warns @MorawieckiM. “The choice could hardly be simpler: either you support Ukraine or you support Russia. There is no middle ground” https://t.co/6kYnLscDEM
Will Finland and Sweden join NATO? “My reckoning is that it will happen,” says @CarlBildt, the former prime minister of Sweden, on “The Economist Asks” podcast https://t.co/k4Jkz5IFFg
Stiff tariffs on Russian energy would lower demand for its hydrocarbons—and cut the European funds fuelling Vladimir Putin’s war machine https://t.co/7VLmCC2cZ8
It would be rash to assume that Russian forces will be as incompetent in the east as they were around Kyiv https://t.co/iXPxS4avgB

Some thoughts on last night’s Macron v Le Pen debate. She needed to show she's fit to govern (she didn’t). He needed to avoid patronising her (he couldn’t help himself, mostly with body language). But Macron clearly outclassed her on competence, precision + coherence. Highlights: https://t.co/TNpITvoN1b
The Kremlin’s intelligence services have been set back by years https://t.co/SaJb2JEJoK
Radios may be less lethal than weapons, but Russia’s failure to invest in communications is hobbling its forces https://t.co/XKLZwiwL47

Vladimir Putin wants to grab the rest of Donbas and other bits of southern and eastern Ukraine. That may not sound as important as the siege of Kyiv, but the consequences of a Russian victory would be almost as bad https://t.co/IpK2Z2TBzZ
Russia has warned NATO that it may strike countries that supply or aid Ukrainian forces, and has even hinted it might use nuclear weapons. That is unjustified https://t.co/0FuyBYVQfp
“One country, two systems” was always doomed. But nobody told Hong Kong https://t.co/0uRTcOlYpp

Vladimir Putin’s invasion of Ukraine is “one of the worst strategic decisions any leader of a powerful country has made in decades”, argues @ianbremmer. In a guest essay, he explains why https://t.co/8tJ2FsqALk

Good piece by @mattsteinglass. "The scale of Soviet & Chinese supplies of heavy weaponry to the North Vietnamese dwarfs anything imaginable in Ukraine...Soviet trainers often pressed the buttons on anti-aircraft missile[s] that shot down American fighters" https://t.co/dsWMboalrx

“This war is about more than politics and more than gas and oil,” writes the chief military chaplain for the Ukrainian Greek-Catholic Church. “The nature of our humanity is at stake” https://t.co/0OpmsLm3ds

Some 7,000 Russians are now stuck in Thailand, with 11,500 more in Sri Lanka and more than 19,000 on Bali, an Indonesian island. They are feeling the pinch
https://t.co/eoDYAD87nJ
